comments.body:
You need to setup the connection parameters and then use them in each of your tasks, like in:
https://github.com/ansible/ansible/blob/76392649308a51622808b79172c689a3ee41ed24/test/integration/targets/elb_target/playbooks/roles/elb_target/tasks/main.yml#L10-L26

I fix the issue with the zip of the lambda source, but I run - **sometimes** into the same assume error you've got.  
 `The role defined for the function cannot be assumed by Lambda`. Run it a few times in a row without deleting the role (and ansible doesn't detect a change), it is accepted. Dunno what here the problem is?




I'm now able to run the integration test: https://gist.github.com/markuman/6a4e7bf57ce78900a4e025c73f8e556c  
But the `elb_target` test fails for me due some region missconfiguration.  
the `elb_lambda_target` succeeded too, but might fail with the iam_role thing described above.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +10,14 @@
- name: set up lambda as elb_target

  block:
    - name: create zip to deploy lambda code

comments.body: Not sure about this one, these timeouts generally address problems that happen only intermittently.  I'm leaving this test on a loop locally 100x overnight, will report back if it hits any issues with the lower value.
So far I haven't seen any failures from the reduced pause.
Are you good with the reduced pause here?
Yeah seems to be fine as best I can test, we'll see what happens once it hits CI for real but I haven't been able to trigger any issues at least.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +26,30 @@    - name: when it is too fast, the role is not usable.
      pause:
        seconds: 10

    - name: deploy lambda.zip to ansible_lambda_target function
